qas.question: What are the people of St. Barts called?
Of what nation do the people of St. Barts claim citizenship?
What is the native language of St. Barts?
How does the determination between Patois and Creole French usually determined?
About how many people speak Patois French in St. Barts?
How many people speak English on Saint-Barthelemy?
How many Anglophones are there on Saint-Barthelemy?
How many people comprised the first settlers?
How many people speak Creole French?
On what side of the island do the Anglophone community live?

context: Residents of Saint-Barthélemy (<a0_0>Saint-Barthélemoise<a0_0/> people) are <a1_0>French<a1_0/> citizens and work at establishments on the island. Most of them are descendants of the first settlers, of Breton, Norman, Poitevin, Saintongeais and Angevin lineage. <a2_0>French<a2_0/> is the native tongue of the population. English is understood in hotels and restaurants, and a small population of Anglophones have been resident in Gustavia for many years. The St. Barthélemy French patois is spoken by some <a4_0><b5_0><b6_0><b7_0><b8_0>500–700<b8_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/><a4_0/> people in the leeward portion of the island and is superficially related to Quebec French, whereas Créole French is limited to the <b9_0>windward<b9_0/> side. Unlike other populations in the Caribbean, language preference between the Créole and Patois is geographically, and not <a3_0>racially<a3_0/>, determined.[page needed]
